name: pre-oe-a-fronting
notes: The fronting to ǣ is specific to West Saxon; Kentish and Anglian dialects had ē instead (Ringe 2014:149)

name: oe-palatal-diphtongization
notes: This sound change is specific to West Saxon dialects

name: oe-i-syncope-near-l
notes: Ringe 2014:276: the sound change responsible for these instances of syncope was arrested before it went to completion

name: oe-postconsonantal-j
notes: TODO: according to Ringe this is restricted to heavy syllables, but isn't every syllable heavy if it ends with consonant and 'j'?

name: oe-back-umlaut
notes: This is the WS version of the rule. In Anglian dialects, 'i' was umlauted to 'io' before all consonants except velars, and before all consonants in Kentish (Ringe 2014:320). In non-WS dialects, back-umlaut of *e was triggered by both and u and operated across any intervening consonant, except that in Anglian dialects it was blocked by velars (Ringe 2014:325).

name: oe-long-ae-retraction
notes: Ringe 2014:199: The stressed ǣ existed only in West Saxon dialects at the time. The results of this sound change were mostly levelled out.

name: oe-diphthong-i-umlaut
notes: This is the West Saxon version of the rule.
